utterances: Yeah, kicking out all the intelligence officers, which we believe...
...And shutting their consulates.
(Unintelligible) their consulates, and we got rid of most of them.
And we've seen a significant reduction in their intelligence collection here in the U.S.
So the consulates were home base for that, and I think for the first time...
Not to get hung up on the numbers, but...
Sure.
...Where would you put it now?
We were successful in getting approximately 70 kicked out.
I have to point out that they did the same thing.
They kicked out a bunch of our people and shut our consulates.
Has the U.S.
also suffered...
We have in...
...In terms of trying to collect intelligence on the ground in Russia?
Great question, Mary Louise.
And we have, but I think we knew making this decision from a policy perspective - the White House knew that when we made a decision to - we call PNG all these Russian diplomats...
Persona non grata.
Right - that the Russians would retaliate.
And we had to be able to be in a posture to facilitate working in a minimalist mentality in Moscow.
And we were, for the first time, OK with doing that because we knew long-term, we had to equal the battlefield 'cause I can tell you we did not have anywhere near a hundred diplomats in Moscow.
Are you using the term diplomats loosely?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
(Laughter) On that note, I have to ask you about the whistleblower and the story that's currently dominating Washington and the nation.
Understanding there's much you can't comment on, are you comfortable with how things have unfolded these last couple weeks?
I think it depends on where you sit.
From where you sit.
Yeah, from where I sit, I am, and I'll tell you why.
In the intelligence community, we have and we sit by the whistleblower protection.

The legislation that was set forth is critical for us because we would prefer someone be a whistleblower in the venue that this current whistleblower did than not give the classified information to the media or to a foreign entity.
If I hear you right, you're saying the process worked.

Somebody who thought they saw behavior - not - I'm not asking you to characterize it - but thought they saw behavior that they were uncomfortable with or that crossed a line - that they were able to report it through the proper channels.
It maybe took a little while, but it has reached the people it was intended to reach.
That would be correct.
As a whistleblower fan, I think the process worked the right way.
Given that, can you speak to the delay that it took to reach the intelligence committees?
The DNI knew about this for a while, and it wasn't reported.

Yeah, unfortunately, I would not have optic to that, which is a good reason because I think the individuals that are in the center of that circle need to remain small and precise in - to protect the whistleblower.
Acting DNI Maguire says he doesn't know who the whistleblower is.
Do you?
I do not, and I don't expect to.
And I think that's great that the DNI does not know that because I think that's the - one of the more fundamental parts of being a whistleblower is to avail yourself to that protective measure.
And I think right now, the process continues to work.
Well, I think, in my opinion, the Whistleblower Protection Act is set forth to be able to protect the whistleblower from any reprisals or any kind of punishment that may come along.
I think this is a very unique situation.
And I think it's going to have to play itself out.

But I'm a traditionalist in this mindset that if you make the determination - a brave determination to be a whistleblower against any kind of waste, fraud and abuse, you deserve all the protections that are provided you in the legislation.
So with respect to who needs to know that, I think that's for the attorneys involved.
But for me, I think that if I was going to be a whistleblower, I would hope that my identity was able to remain confidential to protect me as I go forward.
So bottom line, you would prefer for this whistleblower's identity to be protected and kept confidential.
If that's what's called for in legislation, that's correct.
Director Evanina, thank you.
You're welcome.
Thanks for opportunity.
Bill Evanina - he's director of the National Counterintelligence and Security Center.
(SOUNDBITE OF BONOBO'S ""KONG"")
And now it's letter time.
Our editor, Sasa Woodruff, is here with me.
Hey, Sasa.
Hey, Tony.
How's it going?
It's going great, thank you very much.
I understand we got some letters about the U.S.
House apologizing for slavery and Jim Crow segregation.
That's right.
Here's one from Michael Brown (ph), who thought the apology was empty-handed, at best.
He wrote, somehow white Europeans in different parts of the world feel like now is an appropriate time to speak out a verbal apology, i.e. Australia, England, now the U.S.
A real apology is done through action, not merely through a verbal, I'm sorry.
If it's really meant, these governments would back them up with equality at all levels, Education, financial institutions, employment, housing, and business development.
Without the action, it's meaningless.
How lame.
We also got some letters for a roundtable last week we called Muslim-Americans Battling Bias.
Listener Fahim Rashul (ph) wrote in to say he liked the segment, but we should have spent more time on the subject.
He wrote, we Muslims are challenged by America to get the word out that our religion is not a religion of terror, but of peace.
We must continue to propagate our great religion, whatever and whenever we can, whether it's mainstream media or in our daily lives.

And then Steve Ford (ph), in Berkeley, California was prompted to write in when he heard the interview with writer Kai Wright, about his book ""Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay, and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York."" He wrote, the book and its description come off as sensationalistic.
The experience of the young men is not the norm for queer young men of color.
Mr. Wright stands outside of the chaos, and says to the world, look, look!
Look at the gory picture that I've painted so vividly here for you to see.
How do young queer people get the message that they can live normal, everyday, boring lives, when those stories are not considered newsworthy?
James St. Claire (ph), in Yemassee, South Carolina, praised our month-long series on jazz.
I loved the show this evening, he wrote, and plan to purchase works by the musicians featured.
I have been waiting for some jazz-chamber fusion, and am grateful for the introduction.
Farai's question about, how do you define success?, was brilliant.
Keep up the good work.
Then, listener Dukaoni (ph) wrote in after hearing a discussion on our sports bloggers' roundtable about American athletes playing for foreign countries during the Olympics.
(Soundbite of NPR's News & Notes, July 31, 2008)
The fact that Chris Kaman and Becky Hammon were born, raised here, played here in college and in the pros, they have no allegiance whatsoever to these other countries.
I don't think they should be allowed to play for the other countries.
He wrote, sadly, I did not hear anyone mention the scores of athletes from around the world that are given a fast-track to U.S.
citizenship to enable them to compete as U.S.
citizens at the Olympics, from Hakeem Olajuwon of yesteryear, to the majority of the U.S.A.
soccer team.
Why is it suddenly not OK when the tables are turned?
Could it just be a case of old-fashioned hypocrisy on the part of your guests?
You have an interesting point, but there is a difference.
Olajuwon, for example, was in this country a full 10 years before he played for the United States, and he also played college here, as well as in the NBA.
And finally, Robin Barlow Jones (ph) gave us a shout out from Oakland, California.
Just want to let you know how much I enjoy listening to Farai Chideya's show, News & Notes.
It's refreshing, and fresh, all at the same time.
Farai Chideya should do her own ""Black in America."" She has the depth, insight, and sophistication to probe such an extensive, and complex topic.
And that's it for letters.
Please keep your comments coming.
And to write to us, just log onto npr.org and click on contact us.
When you get there, you'll see lots of shows to choose from.
Make sure you pick News & Notes when you write to us.
And be sure to tell us where you're writing from and how to pronounce your name.
